cards.desc:
### Always use the "Subject Card" template to create a new subject. 

# Subject Columns: Person, Place, Object, Event, Technology
Make sure to create your new card in the correct column. To do this, click the card icon in the lower right corner of the chosen column and choose "Subject Card" template.

# Labels
When you create a new subject card, labels are active for all required fields for that card. When content for a particular section is complete (ie - description), you may remove the corresponding label. Do not remove a label until you feel the content for that label is 100% complete.  

# Location
- **Location Name to Display**: Should be written as **City, State** (within USA) or **City, Country**. Always type out full name -- do not use abbreviations.
- **Google Maps Link**: Find the specific location in Google Maps via search or dropping a pin, then copy and paste the URL from the address field. The more specific the location, the better (specific address or road is better than generic city). Example URL: https://www.google.com/maps/place/Peter+J.+Shields+Library/@38.5394406,-121.7512197,16z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x7b5367caeba5025b!8m2!3d38.5398569!4d-121.7491592

# Date
- Dates may be written in these formats:
 * XXXX
 * XXXX/XXXX
 * XXXX/present
 * Month XXXX
 * Month XX, XXXX
 * Month XX/XX, XXXX
 * circa XXXX
 * unknown

- For people, use birth/death dates (if alive, "present" in lieu of death date)
- For institutions/locations (ie-winery. city) use open/founding date to close date ("present" in lieu of date if still existing)

# Description
General description of the subject / highlights associated with the story context. Remember that some specifics will be identified via connections as well. 

Approximate target length: 50-300 words (as succinct as possible is best)

# Learn More
- **Link title to display:** Avoid redundancies. For example, if you link to a wikipedia page, just use the name of the article as the title and do not include the the site name wikipedia. The base source URL (wikipedia.org) will display beside the title. 
 * URL

# Image Credit
- **Source name** Example: UC Davis
 * URL of source
cards.name: Guide: Subject Card Content

cards.desc:
###Always use the "Connection" template to create a new connection between subject cards.

# Connection Column
Make sure to create your new connection card in the Connection column. To do this, click the card icon in the lower right corner of the Connection column and choose "Subject Card" template.

# Labels
### Colored Labels: Missing Content
When you create a new subject card, labels are active for all required fields for that card. When content for a particular section is complete (ie - description), you may remove the corresponding label. Do not remove a label until you feel the content for that label is 100% complete.  

### Black Labels: Connection Words
Unlike Subject cards, Connection cards should end up with a single black label at the end of the content creation process. Black labels are used to identify the connection word that connects two subjects and the reverse  of that word. Every connection card should have one connection word label. If the word you need does not already exist in the list, create a new connection word label. 

# Connection Card Title
Write the subjects and connection word as a concise sentence using only those words when possible. Reserve any further details for the description.

# Description
Describe the connection between the two subjects. This may be as short as a sentence or as long as a subject card.

# Connect Subject Cards to Connection Cards
1. While in a connection card, click the "Attachment" button.
2. Choose "Trello."
3. Search for the card you want and select it.
4. Select "connect cards..." beneath the newly attached card and confirm that you want to "relate both cards." This will allow the connection card to appear on the attached subject card as well.

# Connection Order
It is very important to make sure your cards are connected in the correct order. When you are done, read the subjects in order from left to right, using the base form of the connection word on the black connection label (the word on the left side of the slash). 

### Example:
Connection Label: [ organized / organized by ]
Subject Cards: [ Patricia Gallagher ]  [ Judgment of Paris ]

**Patricia Gallagher - organized - Judgment of Paris**

It should also make sense reading the order in reverse (right to left) using the transitive version of the word on the black connection label (the word on the right side of slash).

**Judgment of Paris - organized by - Patricia Gallagher**

if you find your subjects are in the wrong order, delete the attachment connection and re-add it. Attachments append themselves to cards with the most recent attachment appearing first.
cards.name: Guide: Making Connections

cards.desc:
# Identifier
- chardonnay

# Date
- 1882/1976

# Description
If Cabernet Sauvignon is the king of red grapes, Chardonnay is the queen of whites. Chardonnay is the most popular wine in the U.S. and has maintained its lead for the last decade. Historical references note California plantings of Chardonnay dating back to the late 1800s, but production was limited due to low yields. This is the story of California Chardonnay pre-1980s, when plantings of the grape boomed as the wine grew in popularity.
cards.name: Growth of Chardonnay

cards.desc:
# Quote
Since Chardonnay has been from time immemorial the great white grape variety of the Burgundy district of France, it is surprising how short its history is as a major factor in the California wine scene

# Attribution
Eleanor McCrea of California Sotheby Book of California Wine (1984)
cards.name: Quote

cards.desc:
# Text
- Modest Beginnings
 * Though some records indicate that Chardonnay was present in California during the mid–late 19th century, it had a very limited role. Producers like Stony Hill Vineyard and Hanzell began to work with the grape with great success in the 1950s, but it existed purely on the margins; in 1960 there were only around 150 documented acres of Chardonnay in the state. But its popularity continued to grow at a rapid pace in the 1960s, and after Chateau Montelena's Chardonnay bested some of Burgundy's most iconic wines in the 1976 Judgment of Paris, Chardonnay's boom was supersonic. 
 * The value of the Chardonnay grape to wine producers lies, perhaps counter-intuitively, in its neutrality. The notable grape breeder Harold Olmo said of Chardonnay, "There is little in the way of distinct flavor, in either the grape or the new wine, until the fruit is almost overripe...However, it is exactly this delicacy and cleanness of taste...that make it... a delight to the consumer.
 * Chardonnay and its parent, Pinot noir, are the two classic varieties used in Champagne, in which Chardonnay’s neutral character leaves space for the expression of the mellow aromas developed in the bottle. The finesse of fine Chardonnay wines, opined winemaker, Eleanor Mcrea, "is as unmistakable as Beethoven, [yet] there are many variations on the theme." That Chardonnay "responds gracefully to many approaches" makes it a canvas for the expression of vineyard and vinification. While some pioneering Chardonnay producers in California sought to reproduce the high acid, crisp style of Chablis, or of the richer quality of Burgundy white, still others have worked with riper grapes, acid-lowering malolactic fermentation and oak-barrel aging to develop the now familiar "California Style".
cards.name: Modest Beginnings

cards.desc:
# Text
- From 300 Acres to 100,000
 * At the start of the 1960s there were only 300 acres of Chardonnay planted in all of California. Today the grape is planted to more than 100,000 acres.
 * The California Chardonnay that wine writer Hugh Johnson describes in Vintage: The Story of Wine as having the “buttery, half-smoked aromas and flavours that had … spelt only Meursault, Montrachet, and Corton-Charlemagne” didn’t have a well-defined presence in California until after Joseph Heitz bought, blended, and sold James D. Zellerbach’s last vintages, and showed that California could produce wine that would stand up to top white Burgundies.
 * Timing, skill, doggedness, a knack for promotion, and the Judgment of Paris propelled Heitz’s Chardonnays into an international arena, but the stage for Chardonnay’s rise in California had been set decades before Prohibition, in Livermore, by a group of immigrant winemakers and a San Franciscan whose dry white wine won California’s first international wine award at the 1889 Paris Exposition.  

# Image Caption
- Stanley Ranch Vineyards
cards.name: From 300 Acres to 100,000

cards.desc:
# Text
- Chardonnay Comes to California
 * Chardonnay’s presence among early California wines is hard to trace due to the absence of varietal labeling before the 1930s, variations on the grape’s spelling, and mistakes in identification. It wasn’t uncommon for Chardonnay to be mistaken for Pinot Blanc and Melon de Bourgogne.
 * The grape’s stateside story begins to come into focus in 1882, when Charles Wetmore imported budwood from Meursault and established his Cresta Blanca vineyard in Livermore. Chardonnay roots developed in Livermore nurseries and vineyards as well as in the Santa Cruz Mountains, where Livermore winegrower Paul Masson planted a second vineyard to Pinot Noir and Chardonnay, using cuttings from Burgundy purportedly from the vineyards of winegrower Louis Latour.
cards.name: Chardonnay Comes to California

cards.desc:
# Images
- 1806 Cresta Blanca Farm / livermorevalley_1896.jpg
- Prohibition / prohibitionagents.jpg
- The Wente Family / wentefamily_1895.jpg
cards.name: Triptych

cards.desc:
# Text
- Prohibition
 * During Prohibition, vineyards planted to white varieties were pulled up and the land was planted to durable cultivars that could better survive cross-continental transportation, such as Alicante Bouschet. In "The Story of California Chardonnay," wine writer Elaine Chukan Brown notes that "In the grape harvest report of 1930, total vineyard acreage in California was around 600,000 acres, with the statewide total of white grapes planted, across all varieties, being just 7,000 acres, consisting primarily of Riesling and Sémillon. Plantings of Chardonnay were so small that the variety was not recorded specifically". By the end of Prohibition the Wente and Masson vineyards were the only substantial sources for Chardonnay budwood in California.
cards.name: Prohibition

cards.desc:
# Text
- Chardonnay's Rise
 * After Prohibition, an insistence on varietal labeling by men like Frank Schoonmaker, the Wentes, and Martin Ray led to Chardonnay’s acknowledgment nationally as a distinct wine of value. 
  * The story of a private dinner in Rome, in 1960, during which Hanzell’s 1957 Chardonnay stood up to a 1955 Corton Charlemagne, circulated among California vintners, and after Zellerbach died, in 1963, winegrower Joseph Heitz purchased the last of his vintages at auction.  
 * Heitz’s acumen as a businessman and winemaker; the publication of the first volume of Julia Child’s book Mastering the Art of French Cooking, in 1961, with volume 2 following in 1970; and the Judgment of Paris were further fuel for Chardonnay’s rise. The rest, as they say, is history.

# Image Caption
- 1936 Wente Bros Chardonnay
cards.name: Chardonnay's Rise

cards.desc:
# Sources
- Elaine C. Brown, ["The Story of California Wine"](https://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/the-story-of-california-chardonnay-part-1)
- Nancy Sweet, FPS, UC Davis, 2007, ["Chardonnay History and Selections at FPS"](http://iv.ucdavis.edu/files/24489.pdf)
- Gerald Asher, 1990, "Chardonnay: Buds, Twigs and Clones," Gourmet
- Thomas Pinney, 1989, A History of Wine in America, Volumes 1 & 2
- George Taber, 2005, Judgment of Paris: California vs France and the historic 1976 Paris tasting that revolutionized wine
cards.name: Sources

cards.desc: Charles Wetmore was the Secretary of the California Viticultural Commission from its founding in 1880 until it disbanded in 1894.
cards.name: Charles Wetmore participated on the Board of State Viticultural Commissioners

cards.desc: Grape varieties planted in California in the 19th century were largely based on recommendations made by the Board of State Viticultural Commissioners.
cards.name: The Board of State Viticultural Commissioners recommended pre-Prohibition white wines

cards.desc: Before Prohibition, California's most popular white wines were made from grapes like Green Hungarian, Burger, Sylvaner, Tokay, and Riesling. Chardonnay, now virtually synonymous with California white wine, was grown in such small amounts that it was rarely recorded as a distinct variety.
cards.name: Prohibition reduced pre-Prohibition white wines

cards.desc: Wente Vineyards did not pull up their Chardonnay vines during Prohibition. After Prohibition, they were one of only a few vineyards with Chardonnay intact.
cards.name: Wente Vineyards survived Prohibition

cards.desc: Hanzell’s 1957 Chardonnay was one of the wines tasted at diplomat Morrill Cody’s dinner in 1960. Of the five participants, three of them mistook the California wine as being Corton Charlemagne 1955, a French Burgundy.
cards.name: Diplomat's Dinner tasted Hanzell Vineyards

cards.desc: Steven Spurrier organized the 1976 Judgment of Paris with the help of his friend and colleague Patricia Gallagher.
cards.name: Steven Spurrier organized the 1976 Judgment of Paris

cards.desc: It was Patricia Gallagher's idea to organize the 1976 Judgment of Paris in honor of the American Bicentennial. She was the one who suggested the idea to Steven Spurrier.
cards.name: Patricia Gallagher organized the 1976 Judgment of Paris

cards.desc: 1973 Cabernet Sauvignon from Stag's Leap Cellar Wine, owner and winemaker Warren Winiarski's first vintage, was included in the historic 1976 Judgment of Paris blind tasting. It won 1st place among the red wines from France and California.
cards.name: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars won the 1976 Judgment of Paris

cards.desc: 1973 Chardonnay from Chateau Montelena, owned by Jim Barrett, was included in the 1976 Judgment of Paris tasting. It won 1st place among the white wines.
cards.name: Chateau Montelena Winery won the 1976 Judgment of Paris

cards.desc: 1970 Cabernet Sauvignon from Heitz Wine Cellars Martha's Vineyard was included in the 1976 Judgment of Paris tasting, ranking 7th place among the red wines.
cards.name: 1976 Judgment of Paris tasted Heitz Cellar

cards.desc: In 1936 Wente was the first California winery to produce a wine labeled as Chardonnay.
cards.name: Wente Vineyards released 1936 Wente Chardonnay

cards.desc: In 1963, Joe Heitz bottled and sold Zellerbach's '61 and '62 vintages of Chardonnay at a price unheard of at the time for the wine, $9, elevating the variety's reputation as a premium wine.
cards.name: Joe Heitz sold Heitz Cellar chardonnay

cards.desc: Describe the connection between subjects here (minimum length: one sentence).
cards.name: Heitz Cellar released Heitz Cellar Chardonnay

cards.desc: In 1912 Carl Wente obtained Chardonnay cuttings from the University of Montpellier's F Richter Nursery.
cards.name: Carl H. Wente imported Montpellier's F Richter Nursery Budwood

cards.desc: The Chardonnay population at Wente Vineyards, which came to be called the Wente Clone, derived from two sources, one of which was material Carl Wente imported from the vine nursery of the wine school at the University of Montpellier in southern France around 1912.
cards.name: Wente Vineyards planted Montpellier's F Richter Nursery Budwood

cards.desc: The Chardonnay population at Wente Vineyards, which came to be called the Wente Clone, derived from two sources, one of which was material Carl Wente imported from the vine nursery of the wine school at the University of Montpellier in southern France around 1912.
cards.name: Montpellier's F Richter Nursery Budwood became the Wente Clone

cards.desc: In 1882, Charles Wetmore, then the Chief Executive Officer of the California State Board of Viticultural Commissioners, carried Chardonnay budwood from Meursault to Livermore, California, to plant his Cresta Blanca vineyard and distributed the material to local growers.
cards.name: Charles Wetmore imported Meursault Budwood

cards.desc: In 1882, Charles Wetmore, then the Chief Executive Officer of the California State Board of Viticultural Commissioners, carried Chardonnay budwood from Meursault to Livermore, California, to plant his Cresta Blanca vineyard and distributed the material to local growers.
cards.name: Cresta Blanca Winery planted Meursault Budwood

cards.desc: In 1882, Theodore Gier planted the budwood that Wetmore brought from Meursault on Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton.
cards.name: Gier Vineyard planted Meursault Budwood

cards.desc: In 1882, Theodore Gier planted Chardonnay on his Pleasanton vineyard, Gier Vineyard, using the budwood that Wetmore brought from Meursault.
cards.name: Theodore Gier planted Meursault Budwood

cards.desc: Chardonnay budwood from Meursault found its way from Wetmore's Livermore vineyard to the Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, and from there to the Wente Vineyards, where it was cultivated alongside Chardonnay vines from Montpellier. Through decades of selection, Wente's Chardonnay vines came to be known as the Wente Clone, and adopted by other winemakers seeking to establish plantings of Chardonnay in California.
cards.name: Meursault Budwood became the Wente Clone

cards.desc: With cuttings from the vine nursery at the University of Montpellier and Chardonnay budwood from the Theodore Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, which was planted using budwood obtained from Charles Wetmore who brought the budwood from Meursault in Burgundy around 1882, Ernest Wente began the 30- to 40-year process of selecting only vines with favorable traits and replanting them. Over time this Chardonnay became known as the Wente clone (actually several clones) and was planted in many vineyards in California and beyond.
cards.name: Ernest Wente cultivated Wente Clone

cards.desc: With cuttings from the vine nursery at the University of Montpellier and Chardonnay budwood from the Theodore Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, which was planted using budwood obtained from Charles Wetmore who brought the budwood from Meursault in Burgundy around 1882, Ernest Wente began the 30- to 40-year process of selecting only vines with favorable traits and replanting them. Over time this Chardonnay became known as the Wente clone (actually several clones) and was planted in many vineyards in California and beyond.
cards.name: Wente Vineyards cultivated Wente Clone

cards.desc: Harold Olmo selected promising material from the Martini planting of the Wente Clone, grown at Wente's Stanley Ranch Vineyard in Carneros, California. Through breeding, and heat treatment to eliminate viral infections, the team was able to raise the average yield from one half ton per acre in the 1950s to over five tons per acre. This improvement made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.
cards.name: Harold Olmo improved Wente Clone

cards.desc: The Martini family's Stanley Ranch was among the vineyards whose Chardonnay plantings were established from the Wente Vineyard, and continued the chain of improvement of the variety by hosting the selection work of Harold Olmo.
cards.name: Stanly Ranch Vineyards planted Wente Clone

cards.desc: The Martini family's Stanley Ranch was among the vineyards whose Chardonnay plantings were established from the Wente Vineyard, and continued the chain of improvement of the variety by hosting the selection work of Harold Olmo.
cards.name: Louis P. Martini planted Wente Clone

cards.desc: In 1946, Fred and Eleanor McCrea collected budwood from Wente's Livermore vineyard to plant the Stony Hill vineyard in the Spring Mountain District of Napa Valley. At the time, the decision to plant Chardonnay was controversial, as there were only around 200 documented acres of Chardonnay in California. Stony Hill may have been the first winery to plant a chardonnay vineyard after Prohibition, and the McCreas did so despite warnings from UC Davis that the variety was unlikely to succeed. UC Davis advised the couple to plant Gewurztraminer, Sémillon and Pinot Blanc to protect against the potential failure of the Chardonnay.
cards.name: Stony Hill Vineyard planted Wente Clone

cards.desc: In 1953, Stony Hill Vineyard provided James D. Zellerbach the Chardonnay budwood that was used to plant Hanzell Vineyards. Because the Wente brothers were widely respected for their efforts to perfect California Chardonnay, Zellerbach sought out the Wente clone when planting his 1953 Ambassador's Vineyard. He continued Wente's practice of evaluating selection, gradually establishing vines perfectly adapted to the growing conditions of Sonoma. Today the vines are known as the Hanzell clone.
cards.name: Hanzell Vineyards planted Wente Clone

cards.desc: Selection and heat treatment of the Wente Clone material at UC Davis produced elite clones, FPS 04 and 05, whose dependable yields finally made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.
cards.name: Wente Clone became FPS 04 Clone

cards.desc: The Chardonnay population at Wente Vineyards, which came to be called the Wente Clone, derived from two sources, one of which was budwood taken from the Theodore Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, which Wetmore brought from Meursault, France, in 1882.
cards.name: Wente Clone derived from Gier Vineyard

cards.desc: Harold Olmo selected promising material from the Martini planting of the Wente Clone, grown at Martini's Stanley Ranch Vineyard in Carneros, California. Through breeding, and heat treatment to eliminate viral infections, the team was able to raise the average yield from one half ton per acre in the 1950s to over five tons per acre. This improvement made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.
cards.name: Harold Olmo developed FPS 04 Clone

cards.desc: Selection and heat treatment of the Wente Clone material at UC Davis produced elite clones, FPS 04 and 05, whose dependable yields finally made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.
cards.name: Foundation Plant Services released FPS 04 Clone

cards.desc: Jim Barrett bought Chateau Montelena in 1972.
cards.name: Jim Barrett owned Chateau Montelena

cards.desc: In 1893 Theodore Gier purchased around 260 acres of land in the Livermore Valley on which he planted 125 varieties of grapes.
cards.name: Theodore Gier owned Gier Vineyard

cards.desc: In 1908, Ernest Wente obtained Chardonnay cuttings from the Theodore Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton and planted them at the Wente Estate in Livermore. The Gier Vineyard was the primary source used by Ernest Wente to establish the Wente Livermore vineyard.
cards.name: Gier Vineyard provided Ernest Wente chardonnay cuttings

cards.desc: Wente's Chardonnay vineyard was planted with budwood from the Cresta Blanca vineyard.
cards.name: Cresta Blanca provided budwood to Wente Vineyards

cards.desc: German immigrant Carl H. Wente founded Wente Vineyards in 1883.
cards.name: Carl H. Wente founded Wente Vineyards

cards.desc: In 1946, Fred and Eleanor McCrea collected budwood from Wente's Livermore vineyard to plant the Stony Hill vineyard in the Spring Mountain District of Napa Valley. At the time, the decision to plant Chardonnay was controversial, as there were only around 200 documented acres of Chardonnay in California. Stony Hill may have been the first winery to plant a Chardonnay vineyard after Prohibition, and the McCreas did so despite warnings from UC Davis that the variety was unlikely to succeed. UC Davis advised the couple to plant Gewurztraminer, Sémillon and Pinot Blanc to protect against the potential failure of the Chardonnay.
cards.name: Wente Vineyards provided budwood to Fred McCrea

cards.desc: Fred and Eleanor McCrea found the property that would become Stony Hill Vineyard in the early 1940s. By 1943, they had made the rugged hillside spot on Spring Mountain their home.
cards.name: Fred McCrea co-founded Stony Hill Vineyard

cards.desc: Fred and Eleanor McCrea found the property that would become Stony Hill Vineyard in the early 1940s. By 1943, they had made the rugged hillside spot on Spring Mountain their home.
cards.name: Eleanor McCrea co-founded Stony Hill Vineyard

cards.desc: In 1953, Stony Hill Vineyard provided James D. Zellerbach the Chardonnay budwood that was used to plant Hanzell Vineyards. Because the Wente brothers were widely respected for their efforts to perfect California Chardonnay, Zellerbach sought out the Wente clone when planting his 1953 Ambassador's Vineyard. He continued Wente's practice of evaluating selection, gradually establishing vines perfectly adapted to the growing conditions of Sonoma. Today the vines are known as the Hanzell clone.
cards.name: Stony Hill Vineyard provided budwood to Hanzell Vineyards

cards.desc: James Zellerbach founded Hanzell Vineyards with his wife, Hana, in 1953.
cards.name: James D. Zellerbach founded Hanzell Vineyards

cards.desc: James Zellerbach hired Brad Webb to be Hanzell's winemaker in 1956. While at Hanzell, Webb pioneered a number of technologies in the cellar, including temperature-controlled stainless steel fermentors, controlled malolactic fermentations, and the use of inert gases. He was among the winemakers who pioneered the use of small French oak barrels for aging wines.
cards.name: Brad Webb was a winemaker at Hanzell Vineyards

cards.desc: Heitz purchased, bottled, and sold Hanzell's '61 and '62 vintages of Chardonnay and pinot noir after James Zellerbach died.
cards.name: Hanzell Vineyards sold chardonnay to Joe Heitz

cards.desc: Cresta Blanca Winery was founded by Charles Wetmore in 1882. It was was one of the original Livermore Valley wineries.
cards.name: Charles Wetmore founded Cresta Blanca Winery

cards.desc: Warren Winiarski founded the winery Stag's Leap Wine Cellars in 1970.
cards.name: Warren Winiarski founded Stag's Leap Cellars

cards.desc: Dr. Harold Olmo was plant breeder on the faculty of the Viticulture and Enology Department at the University of California, Davis, from 1931 until his retirement in 1977. Olmo continued his research in retirement, until shortly before his death.
cards.name: UC Davis Viticulture & Enology Department hired Harold Olmo

cards.desc: In 1948 and into the 1950s Louis P. Martini worked with UC Davis and with the Wente family on Wente clones of Chardonnay planted in the Stanly Ranch Vineyard.
cards.name: Louis P. Martini worked with the UC Davis Viticulture & Enology Department

cards.desc: In 1942 Louis P. Martini purchased approximately 200 acres of the Stanly Ranch for the Louis M. Martini Winery. In 1948 Louis P. Martini began working with UC Davis and the Wente family on Wente clones of Chardonnay planted in the Stanly Ranch Vineyard.
cards.name: Louis P. Martini owned Stanly Ranch Vineyards

cards.desc: Goheen developed the index testing techniques and heat treatment therapy for grapevines at the Foundation Plant Materials Service (now Foundation Plant Services). Goheen served as the Scientific Adviser at FPMS from the mid 1950's through 1986.
cards.name: Austin Goheen worked with Foundation Plant Services

cards.desc: In 1961, Joe Heitz and his wife, Alice, bought an 8.5-acre vineyard from Leon Brandel named "The One & Only." It was on this property that Joe and Alice founded Heitz Cellars.
cards.name: Joe Heitz founded Heitz Cellar

cards.desc: Chardonnay became one of the first cultivars on which the utility of heat treatment against viruses, or thermotherapy, was demonstrated. In 1964, Harold Olmo took selections of the Wente Clone from the Martini Vineyards to the Foundation Plant Services for heat treatment to remove viruses that were impeding yields. Clones from this improvement program eventually became the most widely planted Chardonnay selections in California.
cards.name: Austin Goheen improved the FPS 04 Clone

cards.desc: University of California viticulturalist, Dr. Harold P. Olmo collaborated with USDA-ARS plant pathologist Dr. Austin Goheen, to select and test promising grape clones. They applied a heat treatment Goheen had developed to eliminate the viruses that reduced grape yields.
cards.name: Harold Olmo collaborated with Austin Goheen

cards.desc: James Zellerbach hired Brad Webb to be Hanzell's winemaker in 1956.
cards.name: James D. Zellerbach hired Brad Webb

cards.desc: Fred McCrea and Eleanor Knox "Charen" Wheeler and were married in 1934 in Berkeley, California. They later founded Stony Hill Vineyards together.

# Location

# Description
Fred McCrea worked in advertising in San Francisco for McCann-Erickson before purchasing the property that would become Stony Hill Vineyard with his wife, Eleanor McCrea.

# Date
- 1926/2013

# Description
James (Jim) Barrett was the owner of Chateau Montelena, which won the whites category in the 1976 Judgment of Paris.

Born in LA in 1926, Barrett served in the navy during World War II. On his return, he graduated from UCLA in 1946 and went on to complete a law degree at Loyola Marymount University.

When war broke out in Korea he was recalled and served as a lieutenant on a submarine. When the war was over, he built a successful legal practice, but dreamt of starting a winery.

In 1972, Barrett bought the old stone Château Montelena property in Calistoga, at the time covered in overgrown vineyards and in serious need of attention. He cleared and replanted the original vineyard with Cabernet Sauvignon vines, hired Mike Grgich as winemaker and released his first wines that same year.

While his Cabernet vines matured, Barrett focused on Chardonnay made from purchased grapes, with the success of the 1973 Chardonnay at the Judgement of Paris tasting turning Château Montelena into a household name.

# Location

- https://goo.gl/maps/sLED9jrSyD5GTpTr9

# Date
- 1941/present

# Description
Steven Spurrier (born 1941) is a British wine expert and train merchant who has been described as a champion of French wine.

Spurrier entered the wine trade in 1964 as a trainee with London's oldest wine merchant Christopher and Co. In 1970 he moved to Paris where he persuaded an elderly lady to walk down the Royal Street. From 1971 he ran the wine shop The Caves of the Madeleine where customers were encouraged to taste wines before they bought them, which achieved recognition as a highly regarded specialist wine shop. In 1973 he started The Academy of Wine, France's first private wine school, which featured Michel Bettane and Charles F. Shaw, namesake of "Two Buck Chuck".

Spurrier went on to stage the influential "Judgment of Paris" Tasting of 1976, when a Chardonnay and Cabernet Sauvignon from California were listed above some of the most prestigious wines of Burgundy and Bordeaux.

Spurrier sold his wine interests in France and returned to the UK in 1988, becoming a wine consultant and journalist. He is now director of the Christie's Wine Course, which he founded with Christie's Education in 1982. He is also a consultant to Singapore Airlines, and consultant editor at Decanter.

# Description
Patricia Gastaud-Gallagher was a director at the Académie du Vin in Paris. She came up with the idea for, co-hosted, and participated in the Judgment of Paris wine tasting event. She was also on the Copia panel that oversaw the rematch on The Judgment of Paris 30th Anniversary. 

After her time at Académie du Vin, Gastaud-Gallagher went on to write influential wine columns in French publications, earned a degree as an enology technician, and was the editorial director of the International Who’s Who in Wine & Spirits. She then became the academic director and director of the wine department of the famous Le Cordon Bleu school of cuisine and pastry. She is a co-author of the book Le Cordon Bleu Wine Essentials: Professional Secrets to Buying, Storing, Serving, and Drinking Wine.

Originally from Delaware, she is one of the few non-French natives to have won the distinguished Chevalier du Mérite Agricole given for distinguished service to the French Wine industry (1994).

# Description
Ernest Wente, son of Carl H. Wente, graduated from the University of California at Davis in 1909 and began work at Wente Vineyards, running it with his brother, Herman, for many years.

It was Ernest who, by 1912, convinced his father to import Chardonnay cuttings from the University of Montpellier in France. With those cuttings and Chardonnay budwood from the Theodore Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, which was planted using budwood obtained from Charles Wetmore who brought the budwood from Meursault in Burgundy around 1882, Ernest began the 30- to 40-year process of selecting only vines with favorable traits and replanting them. Over time this Chardonnay became known as the Wente clone (actually several clones) and was planted in many vineyards in California and beyond.

# Description
In 1870, Carl Heinrich Wente came to the United States from Hanover, Germany. He sought out prominent German winemaker Charles Krug and learned the basics of viticulture and winemaking in California’s Napa Valley. 

In 1883, he moved to Livermore, east of San Francisco, and acquired an interest in a local vineyard, soon expanding his holdings to 300 acres in cultivation. Two of his three sons learned the business: Ernest studied agriculture at the University of California, Davis, and took on responsibility for the vineyards, while Herman studied enology at Berkeley and became the family’s winemaker. In the early years of production, the Wentes specialized in white wines, selling their wine in bulk to firms in the San Francisco area.

Charles A. Wetmore planted his vineyard in 1882 in Livermore and established a winery, Cresta Blanca, nearby. # Date
- 1922/1999

# Description
Brad Webb’s contributions to the wine industry spanned three decades with Chardonnay. He made other wines, such as Pinot Noir and Cabernet and even late-harvest Rieslings, but his work with Chardonnay became his greatest legacy. 

In 1956, Webb was involved in the founding of Hanzell by James Zellerbach, ambassador to Italy. Zellerbach loved French white Burgundy, Montrachet in particular, and he wanted Webb to makes wines in the Burgundian style.

Webb pioneered a number of technologies in the cellar, including temperature-controlled stainless steel fermentors, controlled malolactic fermentations, and the use of inert gases. He was among the winemakers who pioneered the use of small French oak barrels for aging wines.

# Location
- Princeton, Illinois
- https://www.google.com/maps/place/Princeton,+IL+61356/@41.3854586,-89.5032144,13z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x8809838e9f03ffc5:0xfb967c780502a8c4!8m2!3d41.3680919!4d-89.4648145

# Date
- 1919/2000

# Description
Born in Princeton, Illinois, Joe Heitz moved to Jack Murphy Stadium while enlisted in the U.S. Air Force. Following World War II, Heitz began taking classes at UC Davis, achieving a bachelor and eventually a master's degree in viticulture and enology as part of the first graduating class of seven to do so in 1951. Heitz found employment under the wine industry extremes, first at Gallo, and then in 1951 under André Tchelistcheff at Beaulieu Vineyard as an assistant winemaker where he worked for nearly ten years.

In 1961, after having worked as a professor at the enology program at California State University, Fresno for four years, Heitz and his wife Alice bought a small 8.5-acre (3.4 ha) vineyard from Leon Brendel named "The One & Only" (later, Heitz Wine Cellar) for $5,000 planted with grignolino, and went into business for himself. His winemaking production preceded Robert Mondavi's emergence in Oakville.

In 1963, Heitz bought at an auction several barrels of Chardonnay and Pinot Noir wine from Hanzell Vineyards in Sonoma, the last vintages of the deceased owner James D. Zellerbach's pursuit of Burgundian excellence sold off by his widow. Heitz blended the wines with success, achieving lucrative prices for the times. A stated strategy for success was to pay growers "what their grapes were worth", in turn increasing the standard of the product he was receiving. In 1964, Heitz acquired an 1898 stone winery with its 160-acre (65 ha) ranch property, which became the Heitz winery and home, with the original winery retained as a visitor's centre.

# Date
- 1906/2006

# Description
Dr. Harold Olmo was a plant breeder and faculty at the University of California, Davis, who released some 30 new varieties, and improved many more. His work to improve the Chardonnay grape is credited with the variety's rise to prominence in California. Olmo worked closely with industry stakeholders, such as Louis P. Martini, to address salient issues in viticulture through his research and breeding efforts. His work first gained wide recognition with the development of grape varieties that married the attributes of the so-called "noble grapes", such as Cabernet Sauvignon, that made them great raw material for wine, with the hardiness that would allow them to be grown in the heat of California's Central Valley, where most of California's wine grapes were produced at the time. 

Olmo traveled extensively to collect grape samples, and in the 1950s, helped establish California's first quarantine facility on the UC Davis campus to permit California growers to import foreign vines. 

Olmo was born in San Francisco's Mission District, and took an early interest in plants. He earned an undergraduate degree in horticulture from the University of California (UC) Davis and UC Berkeley, and a doctorate in genetics, from UC Berkeley.

# Description
Warren Winiarski is a Napa Valley winemaker and the founder and former proprietor of Stag's Leap Wine Cellars.

Winiarski owns and operates Arcadia Vineyards in the Coombsville AVA of Napa Valley, which produces Chardonnay, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot. In 1976, Winiarski won the Judgment of Paris blind tasting for his 1973 Stag's Leap Wine Cellars Cabernet Sauvignon. He oversees the Winiarski Family Foundation, which supports educational and charitable causes, in addition to teaching courses at the St. John's College Summer Classics program in Santa Fe, New Mexico. In 2017, Winiarski was inducted into the 11th class of the California Hall of Fame by Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. for his global efforts to showcase and preserve the quality and history of California wine. In 2019 he was awarded the Smithsonian's James Smithson Bicentennial Medal and became the first winemaker to receive the accolade.

# Description
A recognized a pioneering leader in the California wine industry Louis P. Martini was one of the first to use stainless steel in fermenting and one of first to plant the Wente clone of Chardonnay in the Carneros region. In addition, he was one of the first to use mechanical harvesting of wine grapes.

Louis P. Martini studied at Davis when it was known as the University Farm under the mentorship of Dr. Maynard Amerine, graduating in 1941 with a degree from UC Berkeley. After serving in the Army Air Corps in England during World War II, Martini returned to the winery as vice president and production manager. Martini was a charter member of the American Society of Enology and Viticulture.

Louis P. Martini is remembered and honored for his contributions to the University of California, Davis and the California wine industry with the Louis P. Martini Endowed Chair in Viticulture Department of Viticulture and Enology Agricultural and Environmental Sciences. This Chair is currently held by Professor M. Andrew Walker.

# Date
- 1882/Present

# Description
Chateau Montelena Winery, originally called A.L. Tubbs winery after its founder Alfred Tubbs, was constructed in 1888 and intended as a barrel-aging facility. The Chateau was unique in materials, plan, size, and style for its era. In nineteenth-century Napa Valley, the majority of wineries were constructed of wood. Instead, the Chateau is made of stone with walls three to twelve feet thick, which provides natural insulation against outside heat or cold. Similarly, the structure is built into a hillside to further regulate temperature - something necessary for producing quality wines, but uncommon at the time. 

Today the winery is famous for producing the Chardonnay that won the Judgment of Paris wine competition in the whites category. All of the tasting's 11 judges awarded their top scores to Chardonnays from Chateau Montelena or Chalone Winery, another California wine producer.

# Date
- 1883/present

# Description
Wente Vineyards was founded in 1883 when German immigrant Carl H. Wente purchased around 48 acres of vineyard land in the Livermore Valley. Wente had received training in wines while working for Charles Krug, in Napa Valley. Among the budwood he planted initially was Meursault Chardonnay from Charles Wetmore's vineyard. In 1912, Carl's son, Ernest, persuaded his father to retrieve Chardonnay cuttings from the vine nursery at the University of Montpellier, France, for the Wente vineyard. Today Wente Vineyards is the oldest continuously operating family-owned winery in the United States, and the Wente Estate is registered as California Historical Landmark #957.

The Wente Vineyards are the source of the Chardonnay clone that today comprises a majority of all Chardonnay plantings in California.

# Date
- 1948/present

# Description
Fred and Eleanor McCrea first stumbled across the property that would become Stony Hill Vineyard in the early 1940s. By 1943, they had made the rugged hillside spot on Spring Mountain their home. Fred and Eleanor loved the white wines of Burgundy, and while they would have planted the entire property to Chardonnay, viticulture advisors from the University of California recommended they diversify. They planted the first vines on the property in 1948 to Chardonnay, Riesling and a small amount of Pinot Blanc, followed a few years later by fields of Gewurztraminer and Sémillon. The 21st century has seen the addition of cabernet sauvignon and a small amount of syrah.

Along with Hanzell, Stony Hill is considered one of the original wineries that put California wines on par with the classical greats of the Old World.

# Description
Hanzell Vineyards is a California wine producer located just outside the town of Sonoma. The winery was founded by James D. Zellerbach (future United States Ambassador to Italy) who acquired 200 acres in the Mayacamas Mountains in 1943 and began planting pinot noir and Chardonnay in 1953. At the time, the entire state of California had fewer than 200 acres planted to Chardonnay.

Hanzel would go on to pioneer in the California several winemaking techniques that would become associated with the style of California Chardonnay including the use of barrel-aging, malolactic fermentation, and the use of inert gases and anaerobic winemaking. Hanzell was also among the first vineyards to plant the Wente Clone of Chardonnay.

# Location
- Davis, California
- https://www.google.com/maps/place/Department+of+Viticulture+and+Enology/@38.5331246,-121.7528637,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x808529111d88ec8b:0x568c65130962f704!8m2!3d38.5331204!4d-121.750675

# Date
- 1906/present

# Description
On April 15, 1880, the California Legislature mandated viticultural research by the University of California. In September 1906 the University took possession of land near Davisville (later renamed Davis). The first instruction began with 40 students in 1908. Viticultural work began soon after.

The current Viticulture and Enology Department dates from 1935. The first department chair was Albert Winker. His first hire was Harold Olmo. 
UC Davis became a separate UC campus in 1959, prior to that it was the farm for UC Berkeley. At this time grape growing and wine making research, which till this time had been conducted on both the Berkeley and Davis campuses, was transferred to UC Davis alone.

The Department of Viticulture & Enology is unique in that it combines the grape aspects of pomology and the wine fermentation aspects of food science into one department. The Department is also unique in that it has prime grape growing land for faculty and student use, located in the To Kalon region of the Oakville AVA in Napa County, California.

The Viticulture & Enology Department at UC Davis is ranked among the very best in the world. UC Davis was ranked 28th among all universities in the United States and 13th among public U.S. universities. It is also ranked 2nd in the world in agricultural research.

# Description
Nicholas Higuera was granted the El Rincon de Los Carneros by the Mexican government in 1833. Consisting of approximately 2,558-acres, this Mexican period rancho contained land that would later become the Stanly Ranch. In 1856 Edward Stanly purchased the Mexican grant for $5,000.00. In 1872, his nephew, John Stanly, a San Francisco attorney and later a judge, acquired the property. John Stanly planted approximately 300 acres of vines in the Carneros region. About the same time John Stanly planted approximately 40,000 eucalyptus trees to serve as windbreaks and to provide firewood. Some of these eucalyptus trees still remain and define the Carneros region. Post prohibition, Louis M. Martini first purchased grapes from the Stanly Ranch.

# Date
- 1958/present

# Description
In the 1950s research scientists from the USDA and UC Davis, in response to severe virus infections in vineyards, formed the Foundation Plant Material Service (FPMS). These scientists develop methods for grape virus disease detection and disease elimination. A large collection of disease-tested wine, table, raisin and rootstock grape selections was created which became the foundation for the California Grapevine Registration & Certification (R&C) Program. The FPMS later changed its name to Foundation Plant Service (FPS) and continues its work on the current Foundation Vineyards of over 100 acres. Vines are inspected and retested regularly by FPS and California Department of Food and Agriculture (CDFA).

# Date
- 1936

# Description
After Prohibition, Frank Schoonmaker, a New York merchant, was instrumental in the California wine industry's recovery after repeal. Schoonmaker founded Frank Schoonmaker Selections in 1936 and included California Chardonnay in his portfolio. Schoonmaker, who was critical of the common practice of naming California wines after French winegrowing regions, labelled his selections under the founder's name, followed by variety, producer, and region. 

While Schoonmaker was selling Wente Chardonnay on the East Coast, Wente was also using varietal labelling for their wines distributed on the West Coast. Like Schoonmaker, Ernest Wente believed that the long-term success for the winery was rooted in consumer education, and that varietal labelling was one step in that process. In 1936 Wente was the first California winery to produce a wine labeled as Chardonnay. 

# Learn More

Before Prohibition California's most popular white wines were made from grapes like Green Hungarian, Burger, Sylvaner, Tokay, and Riesling. Chardonnay, now virtually synonymous with California white wine, was almost nowhere to be found. During the state's formative winemaking years in the mid 1800s many of the immigrants that settled in Napa and Sonoma came from Germany and wanted to make the wines that they had drunk back home. By contrast, more immigrants of French origin were settling near the Bay Area and making Burgundian wines.

# Date
- 1946

# Description
The Wente clone was a foundational population of Chardonnay maintained at Wente Vineyards, from which many vineyards established their Chardonnay plantings, and went to eventually create their own named selections.  Ernest Wente refined this population 30 to 40 years, and it became recognized for its potential to produce a "concentrated, well-structured wine". Older selections from this population are now characterized as having small fruit clusters with a high percent of shot berries (millenderage, or hen-and-chicks tendency) and low yield (but good plant vigor).

# Location
- Davis, California
- https://www.google.com/maps/place/38%C2%B032'07.1%22N+121%C2%B047'33.6%22W/@38.5353034,-121.7926782,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d38.5353034!4d-121.7926782

# Date
- 1969

# Description
Harold Olmo brought selections of Chardonnay from the Martini Carneros vineyards to the Foundation Plant Services for heat treatment to produce virus free planting material. Two of these selections were combined and distributed by UC Davis viticulture specialist, Curtis Alley, as referred to as Clone 108, the Davis Clone or the (new) Wente Clone. Throughout the 1960s, most of the Chardonnay in Washington State, and half of that in Napa, was planted with Clone 108.  

In 1969, Clone 108 was disambiguated into FPS 04 and 05, which were registered by the California Department of Food & Agriculture"s Grapevine Registration & Certification Program. This designation is given to selections that have been confirmed as true to variety by experts using visual observations, DNA-based testing or both, and have undergone virus testing.  

This dependable, high-yield clone, and others from this program of selection and pathogen treatment, made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.

# Location

- https://www.google.com/maps/place/526+Montgomery+St,+San+Francisco,+CA+94111/@37.7942183,-122.4050384,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x8085808af4f8539f:0x84fae99c7429ed75!8m2!3d37.7942183!4d-122.4028497

# Date
- 1880/1894

# Description
The Board of State Viticultural Commissioners was established in San Francisco in 1880. The Board's responsibilities were to meet semi-annually to consult and to adopt measures to promote the progress of California's viticultural industries. Each year the board would select one person to deliver at least one lecture in each of the State's viticultural districts, imparting instruction in the methods of culture, pruning, fertilizing, fermenting, distilling, raisin drying, etc., and to disseminate useful knowledge relating to viticulture by printed documents or correspondence. 

The Board's annual reports show early members looking to foreign markets, climates, and geographies to determine what to plant in California. Chardonnay was not listed among the 350 varieties that Agoston Haraszthy imported into California in 1961. Haraszthy's son, Arpad Haraszthy, was the first president of the Board of Commissioners.

# Date
- 1919/1933

# Description
During Prohibition, vineyards planted with white varieties were pulled up and the land was planted with durable cultivars that could better survive cross-continental transportation, such as Alicante Bouchet.  In “The Story of California Chardonnay,” wine writer Elaine Chukan Brown notes that “In the grape harvest report of 1930, total vineyard acreage in California was around 600,000 acres, with the statewide total of white grapes planted, across all varieties, being just 7,000 acres, consisting primarily of Riesling and Sémillon. Plantings of chardonnay were so small that the variety was not recorded specifically.” By the end of Prohibition the Wente and Masson (La Cresta, in Santa Cruz) vineyards were the only substantial sources for Chardonnay budwood in California.

# Location
- Rome, Italy
- https://www.google.com/maps/place/Metropolitan+City+of+Rome,+Italy/@41.8504442,11.9545331,9z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x13258a111bd74ac3:0x3094f9ab2388100!8m2!3d41.9027008!4d12.4962352

# Date
- September 26, 1960

# Description
In 1960, American diplomat and author Morrill Cody invited five guests to  dinner at his home in Rome and blind tasted them on Hanzell's 1957 Chardonnay and some 1955 Corton Charlemagne. Three of the guests, "quite knowledgeable on French wines" and with "a dim view of California wine," mistook the Hanzell for the Burgundy. As Cody wrote in a letter to James D. Zellerbach, "Afterwards, we discussed the relative merits of the two wines and decided that your wine will stand up with any Burgundy. Yours is, of course, slightly lighter in body than the Corton Charlemagne, but that would not be true if it were compared with the Montrachet which it was your aim to produce."

Though Hanzell wines did not achieve renown during Zellerbach's life, the dinner in Rome foreshadowed the Judgment of Paris, more than a decade later, and accounts of the dinner spread through California wine country. After Zellerbach's death, his wife Hana sold his last vintages in barrels at auction to Joseph Heitz. As Hugh Johnson writes in Vintage (1989),  "It was then, in 1960, that the word got out. Hanzell wines, but especially Hanzell Chardonnay, had the buttery, half-smoked aromas and flavours that up to then had spelt only Meursault, Montrachet and Corton-Charlemagne. Nothing could have revived the hopes of California more than this unexpected discovery....the realization that French flavours were within their grasp changed the morale of the industry almost overnight."

# Location
- Paris, France
- https://goo.gl/maps/bMF9XinJpfKeidVo6

# Date
- May 24, 1976

# Description
The Paris Wine Tasting of 1976 — known as the Judgment of Paris — was a wine competition organized in Paris on May 24, 1976 by Steven Spurrier, a British wine merchant, in which French judges carried out two blind tasting comparisons: one of top-quality Chardonnays and another of red wines (Bordeaux wines from France and Cabernet Sauvignon wines from California). A Californian wine rated best in each category, which caused surprise as France was generally regarded as being the foremost producer of the world's best wines.
